msItem.title: Letter from Christ on the observance of Sunday
msItem.incipit: Istud mandatum missum est de celo super altare sancti Symeonis apud Ierusalem in quo scriptum erat istud. Ego deus qui precepi vobis . . . (fol. 263v l. 19) Sic maledicam illis qui iniuste agunt aversus fratres suos. Maledicam illis qui viduas et orphanos male induant. Maledicti sunt qui bona sua dent ad usuram
msItem.explicit: (fol. 264 1. 24) cum ymnis et canticis spiritualibus dies illa transiet.
msItem.note: Not identical with any of the versions of the letter cited by H. Delehaye in Bull. Acad. royale Belgique, Classe des Lettres (1899), 171–213; R. Priebsch in Otia Merseiana 1 (1899), 129-47, or idem, Letter from Heaven, Oxford, 1936, but very close to the version found in the Chronicle of Roger of Hoveden and other chronicles (see Delehaye, pp. 188-9), which it follows almost word for word up to: fratres suos. It is then much fuller. Cf. also MSS. Douce 54, late 15th cent., fol. 1 and Lat. th. f. 19, 14th cent., fol. 24.
In our MS. the letter is followed without a break by a further piece on Sunday
msItem.incipit: In die dominica creata sunt omnia
msItem.explicit: In die dominico erit dies iudicii

msItem.note: Copies of four letters concerning the duties of the rural dean of Deddington (Datyngton), Oxon., in the execution of mandates, to William [Wittlesey 1368-74] archbishop of Canterbury, John [de Bokingham, 1363-98] bishop of Lincoln, and the bishop's officials. In the first letter the rural dean is called 'Robertus vicarius de T.', in the fourth, written to 'Magister Johannes, sequestrator de Oxon. et Bucks', he is 'Thomas Ded.'

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials in red and blue (smaller ones red or blue), with elaborate pen flourishes in red, blue, and mauve extending into the upper and lower margins.

history.provenance: There is an erased note on fol. 2.
Sir Thomas Phillipps: formerly MS. Phillipps 9188.

James P. R. Lyell, 1871–1948: bought by Lyell in November 1937.
history.acquisition: Chosen as one of the hundred manuscripts bequeathed to the Bodleian by Lyell in 1948.
